gnojek

Even the ones that are destined to go extinct without producing any "daughter" species? Apeart from that quibble though, you are right. But don't tell the creationsts; it'll only confuse them ;)

 Well, ok. You're right. 
 
 Now that I think about it, "missing links" and "transitional fossils" aren't really the same thing.
 
 All species are potentially transitional, in that if the line continues it will change eventually, maybe even split.
 
 But missing links are something different.
 
 It's just a fossil that shows some relationship between other fossils and that's really all.
Tastyfish

Surely missing links are transitional fossils that haven't been found yet.
 
 To claim that you have found the 'missing link' makes no sense, as its no longer missing surely ;)
 
 Of course its far more accurate to say there are no transitional species at all, seeing as there are really no speicies anyway....
gnojek

Well, the definition of species isn't so arbitrary but the application of the definition is.
 
 What I mean is, people put things into species not so much because of how they've defined species, but how different they thing a population is from another and that can be quite subjective.
 
 The example I'm thinking of is domesticated animals.
 
 Most of them can interbreed with their wild cousins and produce fertile offspring, but they are placed into different species.
 
 Canis familiaris can interbreed quite nicely with Canis lupus.
 
 Felis catus can interbreed nicley with a number of "different cat species."
 
 
 And then of course "species" doesn't make much sense in terms of asexual reproduction anyway.
Tastyfish

Chuck in ancestors and species that can't breed due to physical reasons rather than genetic problems and the whole idea is nonsense.
 
 Technically you are a different species than your great grandfather
